sen.j: 墾田永年私財法（こんでんえいねんしざいのほう）とは、奈良時代中期の聖武天皇治世、天平15年5月27日 (旧暦)（743年）に発布された勅（天皇の名による命令）で、墾田（自分で新しく開墾した耕地）の永年私財化を認める法令。
sen.e: "Konden Einen Shizai no Ho" means the law to allow farmers to own permanently their newly cultivated lands, which law was proclaimed as "choku or mikotonori" (an order under the name of Emperor) on June 27, 743, in the reign of Emperor Shomu in the middle of the Nara Period.

"Konden Einen Shizai no Ho" was a law which was proclaimed as "choku or mikotonori" (an order under the name of Emperor) on June 27, 743, during the reign of Emperor Shomu in the middle of the Nara Period that allowed permanent ownership of "konden" (land that farmers newly cultivated).

sen.j: 当時の根本法令であった律令においては、原則として国の土地は全て国有地であり、公の土地を民衆へ耕作割り当てを行い（口分田）、その収穫から徴税する（租）と規定されていた。
sen.e: According to then fundamental laws, the Ritsuryo Codes, whole lands in the country were basically state-owned, and such public lands were allotted to common people for their cultivation (this allottment was called "kubunden") subject to taxation to be paid from their harvests (this tax was called "so").

sen.e: Most of the Jorisei system of land subdivision that exist everywhere in Japan except Hokkaido and Okinawa, are believed to have begun after the middle of the Nara Period.

sen.j: このことから、各地の条里は墾田永年私財法に伴って開発された墾田を中心として施行されたのではないかと考えられている。
sen.e: From this idea, it is also believed that all-over Jori works (subdivision of land) across Japan were promoted centering around each field cultivated with Konden Einen Shizai Law.
As a result, it is considered that Jori in various places was enforced around cultivated land which was developed by the Konden Einen Shizai Law.
